context: For nearly <a3_0>2000 years<a3_0/>, <b8_0>Sanskrit<b8_0/> was the language of a cultural order that exerted influence across <b13_0>South Asia<b13_0/>, Inner Asia, Southeast Asia, and to a certain extent <b14_0>East Asia<b14_0/>. A significant form of post-<b9_0>Vedic Sanskrit<b9_0/> is found in the Sanskrit of <a4_0><b15_0>Indian epic poetry<b15_0/><a4_0/>—<a0_0>the <a5_0>Ramayana and Mahabharata<a5_0/><a0_0/>. The <b10_0>deviations<b10_0/> from Pāṇini in the epics are generally considered to be on account of interference from <a6_0><b16_0>Prakrits<b16_0/><a6_0/>, or innovations, and not because they are pre-Paninian. Traditional Sanskrit scholars call such deviations ārṣa (आर्ष), meaning 'of the ṛṣis', the traditional title for the ancient authors. In some contexts, there are also more "<a7_0>prakritisms<a7_0/>" (<a1_0>borrowings from common speech<a1_0/>) than in Classical Sanskrit proper. <a2_0><b11_0><b17_0>Buddhist Hybrid Sanskrit<b17_0/><b11_0/><a2_0/> is a literary language heavily influenced by the Middle Indo-Aryan languages, based on early <b12_0>Buddhist Prakrit<b12_0/> texts which subsequently assimilated to the Classical Sanskrit standard in varying degrees.
